M.G.L. c. 111.proposition: Massachusetts law and public health regulations impose obligations on landlords to provide and maintain residential premises in a condition fit for human habitation and to comply with the State Sanitary Code and local health regulations.

M.G.L. c. 111, \u00a7127A.proposition: Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 111 (Public Health), including authorities to promulgate and enforce sanitary rules and obligations (see M.G.L. c. 111, §127A and related provisions);

Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071, 1076–78 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing implied warranty of habitability and tenant remedies)
Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.proposition: Courts across jurisdictions have long recognized that failures to remediate conditions such as mold, inadequate ventilation, and other defects that materially affect habitability and health can constitute breaches of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and give rise to tenant damages and other remedies.

Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y..raw_text: Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y.2d 316 (1979).
Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y..proposition: Courts across jurisdictions have long recognized that failures to remediate conditions such as mold, inadequate ventilation, and other defects that materially affect habitability and health can constitute breaches of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and give rise to tenant damages and other remedies.
Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y..case_name: Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell
Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y..support_reasoning: The opinion clearly recognizes an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases and holds that conditions adversely affecting health and safety (e.g., garbage accumulation, vermin, inadequate sanitation) can breach that warranty and justify rent abatement. However, it does not frame these failures as breaches of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it discuss mold or inadequate ventilation specifically, or survey ‘courts across jurisdictions’ in that context. The case is strong authority on habitability-based rent abatement and tenant remedies, but not on the specific proposition about quiet enjoyment and the cited types of conditions.
Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y..relevant_excerpt: “A residential lease is now effectively deemed a sale of shelter and services by the landlord who impliedly warrants: first, that the premises are fit for human habitation; second, that the condition of the premises is in accord with the uses reasonably intended by the parties; and, third, that the tenants are not subjected to any conditions endangering or detrimental to their life, health or safety… [T]he failure of petitioner to provide adequate sanitation removal, janitorial and maintenance services materially impacted upon the health and safety of the tenants and permitted them an abatement in their contracted-for rent.”

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.raw_text: Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984) (recognizing that jurisdictions uniformly recognize obligations — cited for persuasive authority);
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: - Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984) (recognizing that jurisdictions uniformly recognize obligations — cited for persuasive authority);
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The proposition as phrased is circular and vague: it repeats the case citation and says only "recognizing that jurisdictions uniformly recognize obligations" without specifying which obligations. Hilder clearly recognizes and adopts an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases and discusses widespread modern acceptance of that doctrine, but it does not contain a clear statement that "jurisdictions uniformly recognize obligations" in any broad, generic sense. Because the claimed proposition is not a well-defined legal principle traceable to a specific holding or passage, the opinion cannot be said to support it as stated.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: Therefore, we now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease, whether oral or written, that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation. This warranty of habitability is implied in tenancies for a specific period or at will.

Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal. 3d 616.raw_text: Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal. 3d 616 (1974) (discussing tenant remedies for uninhabitable premises) [persuasive authority];
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal. 3d 616.proposition: - Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal. 3d 616 (1974) (discussing tenant remedies for uninhabitable premises) [persuasive authority];
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal. 3d 616.support_reasoning: The proposition describes Green v. Superior Court as discussing tenant remedies for uninhabitable premises. The opinion expressly recognizes a common-law implied warranty of habitability in residential leases and holds that breach of this warranty can be raised as a defense (with rent abatement) in unlawful detainer actions, detailing both the nature of the warranty and the damage/abatement remedies. This squarely concerns and articulates tenant remedies when premises are uninhabitable, so the citation is accurate and well-supported.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal. 3d 616.relevant_excerpt: “We have concluded that a warranty of habitability is implied by law in residential leases in this state and that the breach of such a warranty may be raised as a defense in an unlawful detainer action. Under the implied warranty which we recognize, a residential landlord covenants that premises he leases for living quarters will be maintained in a habitable state for the duration of the lease. … [T]he tenant’s damages shall be measured by the difference between the fair rental value of the premises if they had been as warranted and the fair rental value of the premises as they were….”
